caption: Figure 1: An illustration of meta-training in Automated Continual Learning (ACL) for a self-referential/modifying weight matrix Wo. Weights Wa obtained by observing examples for Task A (blue) are used to predict a test example for Task A. Weights WA,в obtained by observing examples for Task A then those for Task B (yellow) are used to predict a test example for Task A (backward transfer) as well as a test example for Task B (forward transfer).
description: This figure illustrates the meta-training process of Automated Continual Learning (ACL).  It shows a self-referential weight matrix (Wo) which is sequentially modified by observing examples from different tasks (Task A and Task B). The weights (Wa and WA,B) learned after observing examples from each task are used to make predictions.  The key concept shown is the ability of the model to perform backward transfer (predicting Task A after learning Task B) and forward transfer (predicting Task B after learning Task A).

caption: Figure 2: ACL/No-case meta-training curves displaying 6 individual meta-training loss terms, when the last term of the ACL objective (the backward tranfer loss; “Task A ACL bwd” and “Task B ACL bwd
description: This figure shows two plots of meta-training curves.  Each plot displays six curves representing the loss values for different scenarios during the meta-training process. The scenarios involve learning two tasks simultaneously or sequentially, while enabling or disabling the backward transfer term of the ACL objective. These curves visually illustrate the impact of the backward transfer term on preventing catastrophic forgetting. The plots provide insights into the dynamics of learning and forgetting in continual learning settings.
